title: Have you or anyone you know ever lied in SSB and still got recommended? - Quora

response.answer_text: To be fair, yes I have pulled off a big lie. Not very proud of it but it has led me to be serving right now so I guess it works. Like many others I was a defence aspirant since school. I cracked SSB for both NDA and TES entries. After much convincing by my parents, I chose TES entry over NDA. But fauj was nothing like I had thought it to be. Coming from a totally civil background I did not have the slightest of idea about the training. It was like my worst nightmare. I must say I was weak and mentally not ready to take all that toil. Not that it cannot be done, thousands have done it before and after me. But I just lost hope and wanted to go home. So I put in my papers and left the IMA after only about 45 days of training. I pursued my graduation after coming out but started missing fauj badly. Seeing my course mates get commissioned four years later filled me with guilt and envy. So I decided to go back. The catch was what am I supposed to answer in the interview whenever this question pops up. I knew it invariably will. I kept getting conferenced out every SSB I went to because I accepted that I was wrong in leaving the academy. Then came my last attempt owing to age criteria. This was make or break for me. 6 years had passed since I left the academy. In this last SSB I decided to lie. When the dreaded question came as to why, despite being recommended twice earlier, I am sitting here, I gave a lie instead of the true story. I told the IO that I could never join the training. I said that joining for both those courses was simultaneous and I injured myself just days before joining and could never join. Call it luck or whatever. I got recommended, cleared my medicals and this time completed my training successfully with a great merit. I even got my first choice of arm. So life has indeed come full circle. I don't know what I did or said was right or wrong morally. But I prepared myself hard physically all those years to endure the training and other things that go on in the academy.

Yes , I lied and yes ,I got recommended as well ! It was in the ssb I gave in january 2014 at 4 afsb Varanasi for NDA 132 course . My interview was going pretty good till then but suddenly interviewer fired one question all of a sudden- Q- Akshay at what time do you generally wake up in the morning ? A- If I was adhered to tell ye truth here then he won't have sleveted me for sure , I mean who will recommend a guy for such a tough job who generally wakes up at 7 am minimum(school days) . But I regained all my strength and decided to lie about that .. I told him that Sir , I moslty wake up at 5 am .(utter bullshit ,I haven't even woke up this early in exam days ) . The look on his face suggested that he dsnt believe me and there comes another question - What do you do waking up so early ? Another dilemma situation for me - have to lie more to cover the other lie. I told him that Sir everyone in my famliy wakes up early as we have our roots from the village . My father had made me habitual to it as he always suggests me “early bird catches the worm” and says that if you won't rise early morning you will lack behind this world. So as per my schedule I do stargazing for a while to get some positivity if the weather allows me to ..after that jogging and exercise makes my day. ( I totally made all these things ,my father won't even know what this proverb would mean . Even I was shocked by my fluency because being from western UP we don't really have much fluent conversations in English! So I think that if there is no option left with you other than lying and I could save your day then you should lie, but it's in you that you have to make it look that every word you spoke is true. Be confident about it and try to speak in English at ssb as much as possible . P.s. - I was rejected in medicals due to my weak eyesight extending the permissible limits.

To start off with, I have. I had lied various times in my SSB interview and yet got recommended. That does not mean that I recommend someone to prefer lying than being honest. But the interviewer sitting on the other side looks for Officer Like Qualities in you and if a lie can help you, why not try it? But that does not mean you have to lie every time you can. Interviewing Officer is a very experienced and smart person, if you lie, you have to make sure that he doesn't catch you red handed. That would end up to be worse. I'll give a few examples- Q. Do you have a girlfriendI denied. If I would have said him a yes, I would have given him an opportunity to ask me more questions about it. The reason I gave not to have one was that I am a very dedicated towards my NDA selection and spend all my free time to it's preparation considering the fact that I hardly get any with my busy college schedule. Having a girlfriend in such a situation is a mess and I just don't want to get distracted right now. That reply not only proved my determination to get selected but also made sure that I didn't get caught as I already had told him about my busy schedule. Do you drink?I denied. I actually don't but the reason I gave was not true. He was constantly stressing that I come from Mumbai and my college location too is such that I obviously was around people who drink. I agreed that my friends drink and smoke. I said that it is their decision to do so and they respect mine to not. I just don't like the taste of alcohol and don't want to reach home slouched one day. Smoking reduces stamina so I stay away from it. However, I agreed that I party with my friends and I know how to drive car even though being under age. This made sure that I didn't have an image of a dull boy in front of him. There's a list of lies like these. It's okay to lie in the interview provided that you are smart enough to know where and when to say them.

Yes I did . No I didn't. Very 1st day at 12 SSB bangalore,The question popped up,by the officer who welcomed us before starting 1st day task. Officer:-Ok who all are from defence background, instantly approx 20 guys raised hand out of 116. After 10 sec or so I also raised, Officer :- : What happened were u sleeping? Me:No Sir , I could not hear properly what you said, Officer :- Ok ok fine ,well guys its just for information nothing to do with selection. Final day during Interview I was asked, Interviewing Officer :- So Mathew you are the same guy na who raised hand after everyone did, when asked who all have military background?” Me:-Yes Sir. Interviewing Officer :- So who is in Defense from your family? Me:- No one Sir, I will be the 1st. Interviewing Officer :- So why you lied when asked on 1st interaction? Me:-I didn't sir Interviewing Officer :-What do you mean? Me:-You asked who all gotta defense background? Sir I am born and bought up in Jabalpur MP,One of the biggest military cantonment in India. Behind my House is Gun Carriage factory,Behind My School is Ordnance Factory Khamaria, and all around surrounded by various Military establishments like Signal Regimental center, College of Material Management etc. Hence my background is full of Military.  (He was blank for few second and then gave a smile. Interviewing Officer :-So to understand the meaning of the question you took extra time to raise your hand that day.. Me:- Aye Aye sir I am still confused did I lie or I didn't. Jai Hind ,Long Live Democracy.

Yes. It's me. I lied to the second question asked and also got caught. The interviewer asked me : So, Anurag, you are coming from Pune? What are some tourist spots there? I replied : Sir, Agha Khan Palace, shani war wada, Sinhgad fort… He interrupted me and asked: you must have gone to Sinhgad fort? I have never gone there but got nervous and instantly replied : Yes, Sir. He then asked : how did you go there? I said : by my scooty. He then asked : where did you park it? And here I did the mistake. Sinhgad fort is actually a fort on mountain and you have to trek to go there. I knew these things. So I hastily approximated distance and everything and replied : Sir, 3–5km before the fort. He said : okay, Anurag. So you parked it 3–5km before the fort. You know i am a NDA graduate. I have gone to singhad fort several times. And then he asked me next question. At that moment I knew I was caught. And I also took that nda thing as a hint by interviewer for me that ‘I am more smart and intelligent than you so don't try to outsmart me again’ And I didn't. I didn't lie after that even once. Whatever he asked I told him flatly and boldly. I was recommended later on the next day but I still think that I might not make to the merit list just because of that one small mistake of lying. Edit 04-12–2017 : I have got into the merit list! Yayy

To tell you the truth. Many people lie and these are not just silly innocent lies but proper made up lies which get them recommended. Sometimes, people get so desperate to join defense that they lie to many questions during their interview. Once, during a conversation on this topic, many of my batch mates confessed about lying in SSB. Some even changed their background totally. Some were prepared for certain questions with made up answers which were nowhere true. Some immature guys lie about previous SSB attempts, sports, skills etc. While these are not very good practices BUT SSB Interviewer are also humans and humans are bound to make mistakes. So, some candidates manage to get out clean and become part of our armed forces. Some guys are smart enough and thus do not get caught. They are clean lair. Some patriotic lair, later join RAW/Intelligence. Same is the case with UPSC IAS Interviews. People lie and become IAS/IPS. One of my close friend told me that he made up an incident and lied around it for half the interview. And he is IAS now. Sometimes, there is something you don’t like to talk about or don’t feel comfortable about, so you try to divert (cleverly) from such topics by lying about them. Their is a saying in academy. Beg, borrow, steal. I think they steal a SEAT.

Yes! I lied in PI. IO: Rama (it's me), As you said that your family is facing a financial crisis; then why didn't you take up any job? Me: Yes sir; there is an offer to coach a volleyball team in my college and I will join in the coming month. IO: Why don't you teach students? You have good knowledge. You can take up tuitions. Me: Sir! I’m short tempered and kids aren't that disciplined. Further being a coach will not consume much time of my everyday schedule and will also improve my fitness and hone my leadership skills. The Interviewing Officer was satisfied with my reply. There was no such offer for me to coach any volleyball team. I lied. I was expecting this question before my interview. So, I prepared this answer before the PI. But I had been a coach of my college volleyball team during my graduation. It was a pro bono service. Result: Recommended for IMA 142 course.

You can most probably lie only in PIQ, that too on your hobbies/interests or achievements. Until you have prepared very well and in depth about both, you are likely going to be caught. Rest you cannot get away in any other place by lying.

Partially lie I will say , in my PIQ form i wrote my hobby as dancing . I like to dance only at marriage ( not professional , just for fun ). So IO asked that : So you like dancing , which type of dance style do you prefer . I said bhangra ( punjabi dance ) . Then his next question was to explain 5 major dance forms in India , their origin , why people are more inclined towards western dancing style rather than Indian . By god’s grace I have prepared well and knew about all the dance forms and answered them well. You can partially lie in SSB , but then you should have a complete knowledge about that topic as he will go deep and deep and if you don’t know you will get stuck in between. Its better not to lie or make imaginary awards etc. Result : Recommended but medicals out.

Yes. A guy in my NDA batch lied about the reason for his changing schools in 10th. He had changed it from Army Public School to some other private school. It was due to a ragging event of which he was a part and one of the perpetrators. He discussed it with a squadron mate ( a total ass) who ratted to the divisional officer who then proceeded to screw that guy to the ground. He had successfully lied about it at the SSB. If only, he had kept his mouth shut, he would have been spared a very painful (yet eventful) night. He was allowed to continue with a severe reprimand. But yes, you can cheat the SSB. Hence, this is the reason why several questions are raised on the process.
Hahah, I didn’t lie even one bit in SSB and still did not get recommended.

Lying is very very difficult. I was asked about adventure sports and told that I had done white water rafting. Then the IO went into every detail which couldn't have been answered if you hadn't actually done rafting.
